repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Yemen - Financial Sector
            Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Adjustment Credit
            Project is rated satisfactory in its overall outcome. Two
            key lessons emerge from the analysis of the project. 1) For
            a sector suffering from significant distortions and in a
            country with relatively low technical capacity, a
            policy-based adjustment credit needs to be complemented by
            technical assistance that supports both affected agencies
            and implementation capacity. Lack of a reliable source of
            technical assistance funds caused IDA staff to spend an
            unusual of time trying to recruit outside donors, writing
            terms of reference and recruiting consultants, and
            re-prioritizing assistance based on immediate needs and loan
            conditionality. A related lesson that needs to be stressed
            is that full-time advisors are probably the greatest
            prerequisites to successful institutional development. 2) It
            is important to set realistic objectives that are clearly
            associated with credit conditionality. In this instance the
            level of "prepare and adopt action plan"
            conditionality could have little effect on the achievement
            of objectives. Had such conditionality been tied to a first
            or second tranche release, with the achievement of
            particular actions or indicators conditionality for a final
            tranche release, fuller achievement of objectives would have
            been more likely. Designing the credit in such a way would
            have enforced a more realistic time frame as well.

Republic of Yemen - Financial Sector

repnme.cdata!: Yemen - Financial Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Financial Sector
            Adjustment Credit (FSAC) Project is to support reforms
            designed to increase the soundness of Yemen's banking
            sector and strengthen its role in mobilizing financial
            resources. The reform measures supported by the FSAC are
            designed to: 1) improve the enabling legal and regulatory
            framework for the banking sector; 2) increase compliance
            with international standards of capital adequacy and loan
            loss provisioning; 3) strengthen the monitoring,
            supervision, and enforcement functions of the central bank;
            4) improve bank accounting and auditing standards; 5)
            improve the governance of banks and accountability of their
            board of directors; 6) introduce measures to improve bank
            loan recovery; 7) undertake diagnostic reviews of public
            sector banks to enable the government to decide on their
            future; 8) take urgent steps to reduce the risk exposure of
            two main public sector banks and to privatize one of them;
            9) establish an Accounting Standards Board to improve the
            timeliness and quality of borrowers' financial
            statements; and 10) develop a legal and regulatory framework
            for financial leasing. The FSAC is disbursed in two
            tranches; the first will be available for disbursement upon
            credit effectiveness, the second upon completion of the
            agreed actions.
